body: Earlier this week, the UKâ€™s science minister announced an ambitious plan: to phase out animal testing. Testing potential skin irritants on animals will be stopped by the end of next year, according to a strategy released on Tuesday . By 2027, researchers are â€œexpected to endâ€ tests of the strength of Botox on mice. And drug tests in dogs and nonhuman primates will be reduced by 2030. The news follows similar moves by other countries. In April, the US Food and Drug Administration announced a plan to replace animal testing for monoclonal antibody therapies with â€œmore effective, human-relevant models.â€ And, following a workshop in June 2024, the European Commission also began working on a â€œroad mapâ€ to phase out animal testing for chemical safety assessments . Animal welfare groups have been campaigning for commitments like these for decades. But a lack of alternatives has made it difficult to put a stop to animal testing. Advances in medical science and biotechnology are changing that. Animals have been used in scientific research for thousands of years . Animal experimentation has led to many important discoveries about how the brains and bodies of animals work. And because regulatâ€¦

title: OpenAIâ€™s new LLM exposes the secrets of how AI really works
summary: ChatGPT maker OpenAI has built an experimental large language model that is far easier to understand than typical models. Thatâ€™s a big deal, because todayâ€™s LLMs are black boxes: Nobody fully understands how they do what they do. Building a model that is more transparent sheds light on how LLMs worâ€¦
body: ChatGPT maker OpenAI has built an experimental large language model that is far easier to understand than typical models. Thatâ€™s a big deal, because todayâ€™s LLMs are black boxes: Nobody fully understands how they do what they do. Building a model that is more transparent sheds light on how LLMs work in general, helping researchers figure out why models hallucinate, why they go off the rails, and just how far we should trust them with critical tasks. â€œAs these AI systems get more powerful, theyâ€™re going to get integrated more and more into very important domains,â€ Leo Gao, a research scientist at OpenAI, told MIT Technology Review in an exclusive preview of the new work. â€œItâ€™s very important to make sure theyâ€™re safe.â€ This is still early research. The new model, called a weight-sparse transformer, is far smaller and far less capable than top-tier mass-market models like the firmâ€™s GPT-5, Anthropicâ€™s Claude, and Google DeepMindâ€™s Gemini. At most itâ€™s as capable as GPT-1, a model that OpenAI developed back in 2018, says Gao (though he and his colleagues havenâ€™t done a direct comparison).     But the aim isnâ€™t to compete with the best in class (at least, not yet).â€¦

title: Google DeepMind is using Gemini to train agents inside Goat Simulator 3
summary: Google DeepMind has built a new video-game-playing agent called SIMA 2 that can navigate and solve problems in a wide range of 3D virtual worlds. The company claims itâ€™s a big step toward more general-purpose agents and better real-world robots. Google DeepMind first demoed SIMA (which stands for â€œâ€¦
body: Google DeepMind has built a new video-game-playing agent called SIMA 2 that can navigate and solve problems in a wide range of 3D virtual worlds. The company claims itâ€™s a big step toward more general-purpose agents and better real-world robots. Google DeepMind first demoed SIMA (which stands for â€œscalable instructable multiworld agentâ€) last year. But SIMA 2 has been built on top of Gemini, the firmâ€™s flagship large language model, which gives the agent a huge boost in capability. The researchers claim that SIMA 2 can carry out a range of more complex tasks inside virtual worlds, figure out how to solve certain challenges by itself, and chat with its users. It can also improve itself by tackling harder tasks multiple times and learning through trial and error. â€œGames have been a driving force behind agent research for quite a while,â€ Joe Marino, a research scientist at Google DeepMind, said in a press conference this week. He noted that even a simple action in a game, such as lighting a lantern, can involve multiple steps: â€œItâ€™s a really complex set of tasks you need to solve to progress.â€ The ultimate aim is to develop next-generation agents that are able to follow instructions â€¦

title: The Download: AI to measure pain, and how to deal with conspiracy theorists
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. AI is changing how we quantify pain Researchers around the world are racing to turn painâ€”medicineâ€™s most subjective vital signâ€”into something a camera or sensor â€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. AI is changing how we quantify pain Researchers around the world are racing to turn painâ€”medicineâ€™s most subjective vital signâ€”into something a camera or sensor can score as reliably as blood pressure. The push has already produced PainChekâ€”a smartphone app that scans people’s faces for tiny muscle movements and uses artificial intelligence to output a pain scoreâ€”which has been cleared by regulators on three continents and has logged more than 10 million pain assessments. Other startups are beginning to make similar inroads. The way we assess pain may finally be shifting, but when algorithms measure our suffering, does that change the way we treat it? Read the full story . â€”Deena Mousa This story is from the latest print issue of MIT Technology Review magazine, which is full of fascinating stories about our bodies. If you havenâ€™t already, subscribe now to receive future issues once they land. title: Google is still aiming for its â€œmoonshotâ€ 2030 energy goals

body: Last week, we hosted EmTech MIT, MIT Technology Reviewâ€™s annual flagship conference in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Over the course of three days of main-stage sessions, I learned about innovations in AI, biotech, and robotics.  But as you might imagine, some of this climate reporterâ€™s favorite moments came in the climate sessions. I was listening especially closely to my colleague James Templeâ€™s discussion with Lucia Tian, head of advanced energy technologies at Google.  They spoke about the tech giantâ€™s growing energy demand and what sort of technologies the company is looking to to help meet it. In case you werenâ€™t able to join us, letâ€™s dig into that session and consider how the company is thinking about energy in the face of AIâ€™s rapid rise.  Iâ€™ve been closely following Googleâ€™s work in energy this year. Like the rest of the tech industry, the company is seeing ballooning electricity demand in its data centers. That could get in the way of a major goal that Google has been talking about for years.  See, back in 2020, the company announced an ambitious target: by 2030, it aimed to run on carbon-free energy 24-7. Basically, that means Google would purchase enouâ€¦

title: The Download: how to survive a conspiracy theory, and moldy cities
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. What itâ€™s like to be in the middle of a conspiracy theory (according to a conspiracy theory expert) â€”Mike Rothschild is a journalist and an expert on the growth â€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. What itâ€™s like to be in the middle of a conspiracy theory (according to a conspiracy theory expert) â€”Mike Rothschild is a journalist and an expert on the growth and impact of conspiracy theories and disinformation. Itâ€™s something of a familiar cycle by now: Tragedy hits; rampant misinformation and conspiracy theories follow. Itâ€™s often even more acute in the case of a natural disaster, when conspiracy theories about what â€œreallyâ€ caused the calamity run right into culture-war-driven climate change denialism. Put together, these theories obscure real causes while elevating fake ones. Iâ€™ve studied these ideas extensively, having spent the last 10 years writing about conspiracy theories and disinformation as a journalist and researcher. Iâ€™ve covered everything from the rise of QAnon to whether Donald Trump faked his assassination attempt. Iâ€™ve written three books, testified to Congress, and even written a report for the January 6th Committee.  Still, Iâ€™d never lived it. Not until my house in Altadena, California, burned down. Readâ€¦

title: Improving VMware migration workflows with agentic AI
summary: For years, many chief information officers (CIOs) looked at VMware-to-cloud migrations with a wary pragmatism. Manually mapping dependencies and rewriting legacy apps mid-flight was not an enticing, low-lift proposition for enterprise IT teams. But the calculus for such decisions has changed dramatâ€¦
body: For years, many chief information officers (CIOs) looked at VMware-to-cloud migrations with a wary pragmatism. Manually mapping dependencies and rewriting legacy apps mid-flight was not an enticing, low-lift proposition for enterprise IT teams. But the calculus for such decisions has changed dramatically in a short period of time. Following recent VMware licensing changes, organizations are seeing greater uncertainty around the platformâ€™s future. At the same time, cloud-native innovation is accelerating. According to the CNCFâ€™s 2024 Annual Survey , 89% of organizations have already adopted at least some cloud-native techniques, and the share of companies reporting nearly all development and deployment as cloud-native grew sharply from 2023 to 2024 (20% to 24%). And market research firm IDC reports that cloud providers have become top strategic partners for generative AI initiatives. DOWNLOAD THE ARTICLE This is all happening amid escalating pressure to innovate faster and more cost-effectively to meet the demands of an AI-first future. As enterprises prepare for that inevitability, they are facing compute demands that are difficult, if not prohibitively expensive, to maintain exclâ€¦

title: The Download: surviving extreme temperatures, and the big whale-wind turbine conspiracy
summary: This is todayâ€™s edition of The Download, our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of whatâ€™s going on in the world of technology. The quest to find out how our bodies react to extreme temperatures Climate change is subjecting vulnerable people to temperatures that push their limits. In 2023â€¦
body: This is today’s edition of The Download , our weekday newsletter that provides a daily dose of what’s going on in the world of technology. The quest to find out how our bodies react to extreme temperatures Climate change is subjecting vulnerable people to temperatures that push their limits. In 2023, about 47,000 heat-related deaths are believed to have occurred in Europe. Researchers estimate that climate change could add an extra 2.3 million European heat deaths this century. Thatâ€™s heightened the stakes for solving the mystery of just what happens to bodies in extreme conditions. While we broadly know how people thermoregulate, the science of keeping warm or cool is mottled with blind spots. Researchers around the world are revising rules about when extremes veer from uncomfortable to deadly. Their findings change how we should think about the limits of hot and coldâ€”and how to survive in a new world. Read the full story . â€”Max G.Levy This story is from the latest print issue of MIT Technology Review magazine, which is full of fascinating stories about the body. If you havenâ€™t already, subscribe now to receive future issues once they land. Whales are dying. Donâ€™t blaâ€¦

title: The State of AI: Energy is king, and the US is falling behind
summary: Welcome back to The State of AI, a new collaboration between the Financial Times and MIT Technology Review. Every Monday, writers from both publications debate one aspect of the generative AI revolution and how it is reshaping global power. This week, Casey Crownhart, senior reporter for energy at â€¦
body: Welcome back to The State of AI, a new collaboration between the Financial Times and MIT Technology Review. Every Monday, writers from both publications debate one aspect of the generative AI revolution and how it is reshaping global power. This week, Casey Crownhart, senior reporter for energy at MIT Technology Review and Pilita Clark, FT’s columnist, consider how China’s rapid renewables buildout could help it leapfrog on AI progress. Casey Crownhart writes : In the age of AI, the biggest barrier to progress isnâ€™t money but energy . That should be particularly worrying here in the US, where massive data centers are waiting to come online, and it doesnâ€™t look as if the country will build the steady power supply or infrastructure needed to serve them all. It wasnâ€™t always like this. For about a decade before 2020, data centers were able to offset increased demand with efficiency improvements . Now, though, electricity demand is ticking up in the US, with billions of queries to popular AI models each dayâ€”and efficiency gains arenâ€™t keeping pace. With too little new power capacity coming online, the strain is starting to show: Electricity bills are ballooning for peâ€¦

title: 'I deeply hurt people by moving to Saudi Arabia'
summary: In an interview with BBC Sport, Ashleigh Plumptre says she regrets losing the trust of some LGBT fans in women's football by moving to Saudi Arabia.

title: Humble & sweet, but a lion - the story of the first female Â£1m player
summary: Meet the person behind women's football's first Â£1m player, Arsenal's new superstar forward Olivia Smith.

title: 'People looked at me like I was a something, not someone'
summary: In a candid interview, World Cup winner Heather Fisher discusses losing her hair and the struggle she had with her identity.

title: 'He fixes what needs fixing' - why Raducanu turned to Nadal's ex-coach
summary: Emma Raducanu recently appointed another full-time coach in Spaniard Francisco Roig - BBC Sport speaks to those who know him best.

title: 'He has made young players dream' - the making of Liverpool icon Salah
summary: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.
